Title: Maryland Paint Stewardship
Synopsis: Requiring producers of architectural paint or a representative organization to submit a plan for the establishment of a Paint Stewardship Program to the Department of the Environment by July 1, 2025, and in accordance with certain requirements; requiring the Department to review and approve certain plans, including a certain assessment; prohibiting the sale of certain architectural paint beginning January 1, 2026 unless an approved Paint Stewardship Program has been implemented by certain producers; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Maryland Paint Stewardship Program requiring producers of architectural paint to submit a plan for managing postconsumer paint, including assessments and collection processes. It creates a funding and oversight structure, including a Department review, reporting, and enforcement provisions, to promote recycling, reuse, and proper disposal of architectural paint.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Producers, retailers, consumers, and residents of Maryland who purchase or dispose of architectural paint
innovative_summary: This program employs an extended producer responsibility approach, requiring producers to manage postconsumer paint through planned collection, recycling, and disposal, supported by assessments and independent audits.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could reduce health and environmental risks associated with improperly disposed paint, potentially benefiting children in affected communities.

Title: Property Taxes - Authority of Counties to Establish a Subclass and Set a Special Rate for Vacant and Abandoned Property
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county to establish, by law, a subclass of real property consisting of vacant lots or improved property cited as vacant and unfit for habitation or other authorized use on a certain violation notice and to set a special property tax rate for certain vacant and abandoned property; requiring the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county that enacts a special tax rate to submit a certain report by December 1 each year; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Baltimore City and Maryland counties to establish a special property tax rate for vacant and abandoned properties, and requires annual reporting on these rates and properties.
responsible_party: Baltimore City and Maryland counties' local government authorities
stakeholders: Property owners of vacant and abandoned properties, local governments, and communities affected by vacant properties
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a targeted tax rate for vacant and abandoned properties, designed to incentivize redevelopment and improve community conditions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to improve community stability and property value, which can benefit children indirectly.

Title: Institutions of Higher Education - Admissions Standards - Prohibition on Consideration of Legacy Preference or Donor Preference
Synopsis: Prohibiting institutions of higher education that receive State funds from considering a legacy preference or donor preference as an eligible criterion for admissions standards at the institution; and allowing an institution of higher education to ask applicants for information regarding familial relationships to alums of the institution for data collection purposes.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits Maryland institutions of higher education receiving state funds from considering legacy or donor preferences as criteria in admissions decisions, effective July 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Higher Education
stakeholders: Prospective college applicants in Maryland, institutions of higher education, families of applicants
innovative_summary: This bill implements a policy change by banning legacy and donor preferences in college admissions, emphasizing fairness and equal opportunity. It employs existing legal frameworks without introducing new technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill potentially promotes more equitable college admissions, which can indirectly impact child poverty by expanding access to higher education.

Title: Criminal Law - Indecent Exposure Within the Presence of a Minor
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from committing the common law crime of indecent exposure; prohibiting a person from, with prurient intent, committing the common law crime of indecent exposure when the person knows or reasonably should know that a minor is present and the minor is at least 2 years old and is more than 4 years younger than the person; and establishing a penalty of 5 years of imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000 or both on conviction for a crime of indecent exposure in the presence of a minor.
bill_summary: The bill enhances laws against indecent exposure by prohibiting it when a person with prurient intent knows or reasonably should know that a minor of at least 2 years old and more than 4 years younger than the person is present. It increases penalties for violations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: General public, especially minors and offenders involved in indecent exposure crimes
innovative_summary: The bill primarily amends existing criminal laws to improve clarity and increase penalties, without employing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is not directly related to child poverty but aims to protect minors from harmful acts.

Title: Housing Innovation Pilot Program and Housing Innovation Fund - Establishment (Housing Innovation Pilot Program Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Housing Innovation Fund to provide loans for local housing authorities and county governments to develop mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing; establishing the Housing Innovation Pilot Program in the Department of Housing and Community Development to assist public housing authorities and county governments in increasing housing production and to reward counties pursuing solutions to the problem of housing scarcity; authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation of $5,000,000 to the Fund in certain fiscal years; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Housing Innovation Pilot Program and the Housing Innovation Fund to provide loans for developing mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing in Maryland. It aims to increase housing production through innovative strategies and funding.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Local housing authorities, county governments, and low- to moderate-income households seeking affordable housing
innovative_summary: The program employs a new approach by focusing on innovative, mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing projects without relying on traditional tax credits or tax-exempt volume caps, and prioritizes projects that remain in public ownership.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has high potential to impact child poverty by increasing access to affordable, stable housing for low-income families.

Title: Residential Property - Affordable Housing Land Trusts - Authority to Establish Condominium Regimes
Synopsis: Authorizing a condominium regime to be established on certain land owned by an affordable housing land trust.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the establishment of condominium regimes on properties owned by affordable housing land trusts, facilitating the development of affordable housing.
responsible_party: Maryland State Land Trusts or relevant local authorities involved with affordable housing
stakeholders: Affordable housing residents, land trusts, property developers, local governments
innovative_summary: The bill enables the creation of condominium regimes specifically on land trust properties, which is a new approach to leveraging land trusts for affordable housing development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Potentially high impact by increasing affordable housing options, which can help reduce child poverty.

Title: Tax Sales - Homeowner Protection Program - Funding
Synopsis: Requiring each collector of property taxes to include with each property tax bill a separate insert that describes the Homeowner Protection Program and encourages taxpayers to make a voluntary donation to the Program through a website maintained by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
bill_summary: This bill enhances the Homeowner Protection Program by requiring property tax bills to include information about the program and encouraging voluntary donations through a website. It establishes funding for the program through various sources, including donations and fees collected from tax sale certificates.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation, Office of the State Tax Sale Ombudsman
stakeholders: Lowâ€“income, elderly, and disabled homeowners at risk of tax sale foreclosure
innovative_summary: The program employs a new approach by integrating a donation interface into tax billing and creating an online platform for voluntary contributions to support homeowner protection efforts.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has high potential to directly impact child poverty by helping prevent low-income families from losing their homes which could lead to improved stability for children.

Title: Charter Counties - Comprehensive Plans - Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing
Synopsis: Altering requirements for the housing element of a charter county's comprehensive plan to include requirements related to affirmatively furthering fair housing; requiring the housing element of a comprehensive plan that is enacted or amended on or after January 1, 2025, to include an assessment of fair housing to ensure that the county is affirmatively furthering fair housing; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires charter counties in Maryland to include fair housing considerations in their comprehensive plans. Starting in 2025, these plans must assess fair housing and demonstrate efforts to further fair housing, including addressing affordable housing needs. Counties that have previously completed fair housing assessments must incorporate those into their plans.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Planning, Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Residents of charter counties, particularly those seeking fair housing and affordable housing options
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a mandated integration of fair housing assessments into county comprehensive planning, emphasizing compliance with federal fair housing efforts, which is a progressive approach to enforcing fair housing policies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by promoting equitable housing opportunities and addressing affordable housing needs.

Title: Natural Resources - Northern Snakehead - Common Name
Synopsis: Establishing the common name of the northern snakehead as the "Chesapeake Channa".
bill_summary: The bill establishes a new common name for the northern snakehead fish as 'Chesapeake Channa' and requires the Department of Natural Resources to adopt regulations reflecting this new name by January 1, 2025. It also introduces a licensing system for commercial fishing of the species, with specific regulations on fishing methods, licensing fees, and geographic restrictions.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Commercial fishers, conservation agencies, general public
innovative_summary: The bill employs a new approach by officially changing the common name of a fish species and establishing specific regulations and licensing for its commercial harvest, integrating regulatory updates with species management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty as it mainly pertains to fish naming and licensing regulations.

Title: Agriculture - Pollinator Habitat Plan - Requirements for State Highway Administration
Synopsis: Requiring the State Highway Administration's pollinator habitat plan to include policies and procedures regarding the use of pollinator habitat areas along State highways; requiring the Administration to track and evaluate federal programs that provide funding for pollinator habitats, native plants, and invasive species control and to apply for any funding that the Administration determines appropriate and beneficial to pollinator habitats; requiring the Administration to update the plan by October 1 each year; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland State Highway Administration to include policies for pollinator habitats along highways, avoid certain pesticides, and track federal funding programs for pollinator habitats. It also mandates updating these plans annually and engaging the public about pollinators.
responsible_party: Maryland State Highway Administration
stakeholders: Pollinators, highway users, local communities, environment
innovative_summary: The bill encourages the development of pollinator habitats along highways, public education, and federal funding tracking, employing integrated conservation and community engagement approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program predominantly focuses on environmental and infrastructural improvements rather than direct child poverty alleviation.

Title: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange - Qualified Health Plans - Dental Coverage
Synopsis: Repealing a certain provision of law providing that a qualified health plan is not required under certain circumstances to provide essential benefits that duplicate the minimum benefits of qualified dental plans; and repealing the authority of the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to require children enrolling in a qualified health plan to have essential pediatric dental benefits required by the federal Secretary of Health and Human Services.
bill_summary: The bill repeals certain provisions related to the requirement for qualified health plans to include essential dental and pediatric dental benefits in Maryland's health exchange. It clarifies that health benefit plans are not required to duplicate dental benefits if dental plans are available through the exchange and repeals the authority for requiring children to enroll in dental plans with pediatric dental benefits. It updates the regulations governing the certification and sale of health, dental, and vision plans and sets the effective date for these changes to January 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange and Maryland Department of Insurance
stakeholders: Individuals purchasing health plans in Maryland, children needing pediatric dental benefits, health insurance carriers, and healthcare providers in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill updates and streamlines the certification and offering process for health, dental, and vision plans, incorporating federal standards and offering flexibility in coverage options. It also clarifies the conditions under which dental benefits are included, but does not appear to introduce new technologies or novel approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill may have a moderate direct impact on child poverty by clarifying dental coverage options for children, potentially improving access to dental care.

Title: Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the type of financial assistance that may be provided by eligible fund managers who receive grants from the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account in the Department of Commerce to allow grants of up to $10,000 in conjunction with a loan.
bill_summary: The bill amends the Maryland Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account to alter the types of financial assistance, expanding the use of grants and loans to support small, minority, and women-owned businesses, especially in disaster and emergency situations, and allocates funds from the Strategic Energy Investment Fund for clean energy industry businesses.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Small, minority, women-owned, and veteran-owned businesses in Maryland, especially in disaster-affected areas and clean energy sector
innovative_summary: The program employs a combination of grant and loan funding managed through eligible fund managers, tailored to emergency declarations and clean energy businesses, which represents a novel approach to targeted economic support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: High potential to impact child poverty by supporting small and minority-owned businesses, which can lead to job creation and economic growth in vulnerable communities.

Title: Health Insurance â€“ Conformity With Federal Law
Synopsis: Conforming provisions of State health insurance law with existing federal requirements, including updating effective dates for federal regulations, clarifying federal consumer protection regulations resulting from changes to the federal No Surprises Act, altering the material errors that trigger special enrollment periods, and authorizing the Maryland Health Benefits Exchange to adopt an expanded open enrollment period under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's health insurance laws to conform with federal requirements, clarifies regulations related to emergency and mental health services, and modifies procedures for open enrollment periods and provider designations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Insurance Administration
stakeholders: Health insurance consumers in Maryland, including those accessing emergency, mental health, and pediatric services
innovative_summary: The bill includes some updates aligning state health insurance regulations with federal laws, and introduces provisions for expanded open enrollment and error correction in enrollments, employing existing technology and policies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has moderate potential to impact child poverty by improving access and clarity of health services for children and families.

Title: Property Tax - Submission of Building Permits to Supervisor of Assessments - Estimated Construction Cost
Synopsis: Requiring local permit offices to include a construction cost estimate when submitting a copy of a building permit to the supervisor of assessments of the county where the building is located.
bill_summary: The bill requires local permit offices to include a construction cost estimate when submitting a copy of a building permit to the county supervisor of assessments.
responsible_party: Local permit offices and county supervisors of assessments
stakeholders: Property owners, local governments, and assessors
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new requirement for submission of estimated construction costs with building permits, but does not involve new technology or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Low potential for direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Insurance - Protections After Loss or Damage to Property
Synopsis: Prohibiting a public adjuster, or anyone acting on behalf of a public adjuster, from soliciting or attempting to solicit a client between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.; altering the statements that are required to be included in a public adjuster contract; altering a certain rescission period for public adjuster contracts; and requiring a public adjuster to provide notice to the Commissioner, in a form and manner the Commissioner determines, within 1 business day after the public adjuster has entered into a contract.
bill_summary: The bill enhances regulations on public adjusters, including restrictions on solicitation times after a loss, requirements for contracts, and reporting obligations. It also addresses fraudulent practices related to contractor payments for property damage repairs.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Insurance policyholders, public adjusters, contractors, and insured property owners in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates and clarifies existing laws and introduces stricter regulations for public adjusters and contractors, without employing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Baltimore City - Motor Vehicle Off-Street Parking Requirements Near Mass Transit Stations
Synopsis: Prohibiting the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City from adopting or enforcing a local law that requires the creation of new motor vehicle off-street parking for a development that includes residential use and that is located within a 0.25-mile radius of a present or planned MARC, Baltimore MTA Light Rail, Red Line, or Metro station.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits Baltimore City from requiring new off-street parking for residential developments within 0.25 miles of certain transit stations, such as MARC, MTA Light Rail, Red Line, or Metro stations.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Government (Mayor and City Council)
stakeholders: Residents and developers of residential developments near transit stations in Baltimore City
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a restriction on parking requirements near transit stations, which is an approach to promoting transit-oriented development and reducing car dependence.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by encouraging accessible transit and reducing housing costs related to parking.

Title: Residential Service Agencies - Reimbursement - Personal Assistance Services (Homecare Worker Rights Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Authorizing the Maryland Department of Health to reimburse a residential service agency for personal assistance services only if the personal assistance services are provided by an individual classified as an employee.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Health to reimburse residential service agencies for personal assistance services only if the services are provided by individuals classified as employees, starting January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Residential service agencies, personal assistance workers, individuals receiving services
innovative_summary: This bill primarily changes reimbursement rules and employment classifications, and does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill may indirectly impact child poverty by affecting employment conditions and funding for personal assistance services, but it does not explicitly target child poverty.

Title: Public Health - Public Health Services and Protections - Revisions
Synopsis: Repealing the exceptions that allow the sale, distribution, or purchase of tobacco products, tobacco paraphernalia, and electronic smoking devices to or for certain individuals who are active duty members of the military; authorizing the Maryland Department of Health to reallocate from one county to another county certain projected unspent grant funding relating to cancer to address certain funding needs; altering the duties of the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland's public health regulations by removing exemptions for active military under 21 to purchase tobacco and electronic smoking devices, updating signage requirements, reallocating unspent cancer funding between counties, consolidating child abuse and neglect oversight, and revising enforcement and penalties related to tobacco and vaping products.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Military personnel under 21, tobacco and electronic smoking device purchasers, children affected by abuse and neglect, public health agencies, local governments
innovative_summary: The bill primarily makes legal, regulatory, and administrative adjustments to existing health and public safety frameworks, with typical approaches to enforcement, signage, and funding reallocation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on regulation, enforcement, and administrative reforms rather than direct interventions affecting child poverty.

Title: Motor Vehicle Registration - Exceptions for Golf Carts - Authorization
Synopsis: Authorizing counties and municipalities to designate certain highways in their respective jurisdictions on which a person may operate a golf cart; authorizing a person with a valid driver's license to operate a golf cart only on a highway with a maximum posted speed limit of not more than 30 miles per hour or 35 miles per hour in Golden Beach Patuxent Knolls, St. Mary's County, between dawn and dusk, and if the golf cart is equipped with certain lighting devices; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Maryland counties and municipalities to designate specific highways for golf cart operation. It repeals previous authorizations for golf carts on highways and establishes new rules for their operation, including safety requirements and licensing.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation or local Maryland counties and municipalities
stakeholders: Golf cart operators, local residents, and jurisdictions in Maryland where golf carts may be operated
innovative_summary: The bill employs a localized approach by allowing counties and municipalities to designate highways for golf cart operation and sets safety standards, but does not introduce new technologies or innovative methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty as it primarily deals with infrastructure and safety regulations for golf carts.

Title: Natural Resources - Sale, Barter, or Exchange of Mounted Specimens From Decedent's Estate
Synopsis: Authorizing the sale, barter, or exchange of a legally acquired mounted specimen of a game bird, excluding a migratory game bird, or game mammal, from a decedent's estate and the specimen is part of the personal property being liquidated or distributed.
bill_summary: The bill permits the sale, barter, or exchange of mounted specimens of game birds or game mammals from a decedent's estate under specific circumstances, which was previously prohibited.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Individuals inheriting or managing estates with mounted game specimens, collectors, and the general public interested in game specimens.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a legal exception allowing the sale of mounted specimens from decedents' estates, clarifying legal boundaries for such transactions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is not directly related to child poverty alleviation.

Title: Public Health - Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund and Commission
Synopsis: Altering the use of the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund to require that the Fund be used only for pediatric cancer research instead of only for pediatric cancer research, prevention, and treatment and to allow funds from the Fund to be used for administrative expenses; and establishing the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to oversee the award of competitive grants from the Fund and to develop criteria and a process for reviewing grant applications.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund to restrict its use solely to pediatric cancer research, allows funds to be used for administrative expenses, establishes the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to oversee research grants, and outlines administrative and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children with pediatric cancer, researchers, hospitals, healthcare providers, and advocacy organizations
innovative_summary: The bill creates a dedicated research fund and a new commission to oversee pediatric cancer research grants, employing a structured approach to funding and oversight.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's direct impact on child poverty is limited, focusing mainly on pediatric cancer research and support.

Title: State Employees - Parental Bereavement Leave
Synopsis: Providing that certain State employees are entitled to use up to 10 days of parental bereavement leave with pay within 60 days after the death of the employee's child; providing that certain State employees are entitled to use up to 60 days of parental bereavement leave within 60 days after the employee experiences a stillbirth or the death of the employee's infant; and prohibiting certain State entities from requiring State employees entitled to parental bereavement leave under the Act to use any other paid leave available to the employee.
bill_summary: The bill grants parental bereavement leave with pay to certain Maryland state employees, allowing up to 10 days for the death of a child or stillbirth, and up to 60 days for a stillbirth or infant death, without requiring the use of other paid leave.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management or equivalent state agency responsible for state employee policies
stakeholders: State employees in Maryland, particularly those who are parents or expecting parents
innovative_summary: This program introduces specific paid leave for parental bereavement, which is a targeted and supportive policy for employees experiencing a child's death or stillbirth.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing instead on employee leave rights.

Title: Property Tax - Transfer to Heir or Legatee - Payment Plans
Synopsis: Exempting a grant of land transferring residential real property from the estate of a decedent to an heir or a legatee of the decedent from certain requirements for the payment of taxes on real property if the heir or legatee of the decedent enters into a payment plan to pay all the taxes due and owed on the property; exempting a grant of land that is subject to a payment plan for property taxes from certain requirements for the payment of taxes if the grantee agrees to assume the grantor's obligations under the payment plan; etc.
bill_summary: The bill creates programs and legal provisions to allow homeowners, especially those inheriting residential property from a decedent, to pay their property taxes via installment plans. It establishes a statewide and local framework for installment payment programs and provides assistance through a State Tax Sale Ombudsman.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Assessments and Taxation and County or Municipal Tax Collectors
stakeholders: Homeowners, especially heirs of decedents, and property tax authorities in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a new approach by establishing a state-level taxpayer ombudsman and a vendor-operated installment program, and by providing specific protections for taxpayers in the inheritance process.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has potential to reduce child poverty indirectly by alleviating financial burdens related to property taxes for vulnerable families.

Title: Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families to study developing and implementing a statewide strategic plan to make Maryland the best state for veterans and military families, including legislative and budgetary recommendations; requiring the Commission to consult with the Office of Military and Federal Affairs and the Maryland Military Installation Council as part of the study process; and requiring the Commission to report its findings to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families to study and develop a strategic plan to make Maryland the best state for veterans and military families, including making legislative and budget recommendations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
stakeholders: Veterans, military families, advocacy groups, state government
innovative_summary: The bill creates a commission to study and recommend strategies, including setting key performance indicators for state comparison, which is a collaborative planning approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The primary focus is on strategic planning for veterans and military families, with indirect potential to impact child poverty through improved services.

Title: Rehabilitation Services - Disability - Definition
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "disability" relating to the provision of rehabilitation services in the State to align with the federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973; and defining "disability" as any physical or mental impairment that constitutes or results in a substantial impediment to employment or independent living.
bill_summary: This bill amends the definition of "disability" related to rehabilitation services in Maryland to align with federal law, specifying that disability includes any physical or mental impairment that substantially hampers employment or independent living.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education or relevant rehabilitation services agencies
stakeholders: Individuals with physical or mental impairments seeking rehabilitation services
innovative_summary: The bill updates the legal definition of disability to align with federal standards, which may improve consistency in services and legal protections.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but can improve access to rehabilitation for vulnerable populations, potentially affecting their economic independence.

Title: State Employee Rights and Protections - Personnel Actions and Harassment - Investigation of Complaints
Synopsis: Increasing, from 30 days to 60 days, the time period during which an investigation must be conducted and a written decision must be issued regarding a complaint filed by an applicant or employee alleging discrimination or harassment by an employer; and authorizing certain applicants and employees to provide written authorization to increase by an additional 30 days the time period during which an investigation of a complaint and a written decision must be completed.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum duration for investigations of complaints by state employees regarding discrimination or harassment from 30 days to 60 days, with an option to extend by an additional 30 days if the complainant provides written authorization.
responsible_party: Maryland State Personnel and Pensions Department
stakeholders: Maryland state employees and applicants filing complaints of discrimination or harassment
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a flexible extension process for complaint investigations, allowing written authorization from complainants to extend the investigation period.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty but improves employee protections within the state government.

Title: Property Tax - Credit for Dwelling House of Disabled Veterans - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering eligibility for a certain property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax on the dwelling house of certain disabled veterans to include individuals who have been declared by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to have a nonpermanent service-connected disability of 100% that results from blindness or any other disabling cause; authorizing a county or municipal corporation, notwithstanding certain provisions of the Act, to enact a law limiting eligibility for the tax credit; etc.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland law to expand eligibility for a property tax credit for disabled veterans, including those with nonpermanent service-connected disabilities of 100%. It also allows local governments to limit eligibility based on certain criteria.
responsible_party: Maryland local governments (cities and counties) for implementing property tax credits
stakeholders: Disabled veterans and their families in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill mostly makes legal and eligibility rule changes, with some local discretion; it does not introduce new technological or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Property Tax Credits - Public School Employees, Health and Safety Improvements, and Property Used for Local Housing Programs
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a certain property tax credit for certain residential real property owned by a public school employee under certain circumstances; authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a certain property tax credit for certain buildings if the owner made certain health or safety improvements on or after July 1, 2024; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes local governments in Maryland to grant property tax credits for various purposes, including for public school employees' primary residences, health and safety improvements in apartment or condominium buildings, and property used in local housing programs for the homeless, starting from July 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Local governments in Maryland (Baltimore City and other counties/municipalities)
stakeholders: Public school employees, residents of apartment and condominium buildings, homeless individuals and families, property owners, and local governments
innovative_summary: The bill employs local government authority to create targeted property tax credits for specific community improvements and social programs, which is a standard approach and not particularly innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has moderate potential to impact child poverty by supporting affordable housing initiatives related to homelessness and improving living conditions for residents.

Title: Insurance - Penalties - Unauthorized Insurers, Insurance Producers, and Public Adjusters
Synopsis: Altering the maximum civil penalty to which an unauthorized insurer or person that violates certain provisions of State insurance law is subject for each violation; and altering the maximum civil penalty that the Maryland Insurance Commissioner may impose, in addition to suspending or revoking the license, on the holder of an insurance producer license or a public adjuster licensee for each violation of State insurance law.
bill_summary: The bill increases civil penalties for violations involving unauthorized insurers and individuals violating insurance laws, and modifies licensing rules for insurance producers and public adjusters, including penalties and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
stakeholders: Insurance professionals, consumers, regulatory authorities
innovative_summary: The bill mainly updates penalties and licensing rules; it does not introduce new services or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly target child poverty but may indirectly impact consumers' financial stability.

Title: Continuing Care Retirement Communities - Transparency, Grievances, and Unit Reoccupancy
Synopsis: Requiring a provider to post the provider's most recent disclosure statement on the provider's website; increasing from yearly to quarterly the number of times a provider is required to hold a meeting open to all the provider's subscribers; requiring at the last quarterly meeting of the year an officer of the provider to give an aggregated, deidentified summary of internal grievances; requiring a provider to submit a written report to a subscriber or a beneficiary if the subscriber's unit has not been reoccupied within 9 months; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates regulations for continuing care retirement communities in Maryland, including transparency, grievance procedures, governance, and refund policies. It requires public posting of disclosure statements, regular elections of subscriber members to governing bodies, improved grievance handling, and tracking of refund and reoccupancy data.
responsible_party: Department of Aging
stakeholders: Residents of continuing care retirement communities and their families in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency and accountability through mandated disclosures, regular meetings, and grievance procedures, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's provisions improve resident protections and transparency, which may indirectly benefit vulnerable populations but have limited direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Teacher Development and Retention Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "institution of initial eligibility" to include community colleges as eligible institutions as part of the criteria for applicants for the Teacher Development and Retention Program; altering the evaluation requirements for the Program; requiring the Higher Education Commission to conduct an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Program and report the results to the Governor and the General Assembly by January 1, 2030; and altering the termination date from June 30, 2029 to June 30, 2030.
bill_summary: The bill expands and renews the Maryland Teacher Development and Retention Program, including adding community colleges as eligible institutions, modifying participation years, and extending the program's duration and funding provisions to support future teachers in high-need areas.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: prospective and current teachers, students in high-need schools, and high-need school communities
innovative_summary: The program introduces targeted financial stipends and experiential learning opportunities to encourage teaching careers in shortage areas, with an emphasis on community colleges and early-stage support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a significant potential to reduce child poverty by addressing teacher shortages in high-need schools and supporting future teachers early in their careers.

Title: Health Occupations - Pharmacists - Administration of Vaccines
Synopsis: Authorizing a pharmacist to order and administer certain vaccinations to individuals in certain age groups if certain requirements are met; altering the vaccinations that a pharmacist can administer to individuals at least 3 years old; and altering the circumstances under which a pharmacist may administer certain vaccinations.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes pharmacists in Maryland to order and administer certain vaccinations to specific age groups, including influenza, COVID-19, and other vaccines in response to public health emergencies, under specified training, certification, and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Pharmacy
stakeholders: Children, adolescents, and adults who receive vaccinations through pharmacists in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill enhances the role of pharmacists by allowing them to directly administer certain vaccines to broader age groups, using training and protocols, thus increasing access to vaccinations and modernizing pharmacy-based healthcare services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could improve health access and outcomes, potentially reducing disparities linked to vaccine availability, thereby having a positive impact on child poverty levels.

Title: Maryland Environmental Service â€“ Governance and Requirements
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Maryland Environmental Service to delegate certain responsibilities to an employee of the Service; altering the obligations of the Service after receiving a request for services and after entering into a contract;  requiring that an audit be made of the financial books, records, and accounts of the Service by November 15 each year; and requiring the Service to report to the Governor and the General Assembly on its activities by November 15 each year.
bill_summary: The bill makes changes to the governance, responsibilities, reporting requirements, and audit deadlines for the Maryland Environmental Service, including adjusting the quorum threshold for the board and delegating certain secretary responsibilities to employees.
responsible_party: Maryland Environmental Service
stakeholders: Residents and government agencies interacting with the Maryland Environmental Service
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates operational rules and responsibilities for a state agency and does not introduce new technological approaches or innovative programs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty as it mainly concerns governance and accountability of a state environmental agency.

Title: Hospitals and Urgent Care Centers - Sepsis Protocol (Lochlin's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before January 1, 2025, each hospital and urgent care center in the State to implement an evidence-based protocol for the early recognition and treatment of a patient with sepsis, severe sepsis, or septic shock that is based on generally acceptable standards of care; requiring a specialty psychiatric hospital to establish a certain process; and requiring hospitals and urgent care centers to require periodic training in the implementation of the protocol for certain staff.
bill_summary: The bill requires hospitals and urgent care centers in Maryland to implement an evidence-based sepsis recognition and treatment protocol by January 1, 2025, including staff training and quality measures.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Hospitals, urgent care centers, patients with sepsis
innovative_summary: The bill employs an evidence-based protocol infused with CDC guidelines and mandates staff training, aligning with best practices for sepsis care.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program primarily improves hospital protocols for sepsis; its direct impact on child poverty is indirect or minimal.

Title: Public and Nonpublic Schools - Bronchodilators - Use, Availability, Training, and Policies
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Education, in consultation with certain groups, to develop training for certain school personnel to identify symptoms of anaphylaxis, asthma, and respiratory distress in students; requiring the Maryland Department of Health, in consultation with county boards, and authorizing nonpublic schools to establish a policy to obtain, administer, and train certain school personnel to administer emergency bronchodilators to a student who is determined to be, or is perceived to be, experiencing asthma-related symptoms; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates policies in Maryland public and nonpublic schools to allow trained school nurses and personnel to administer emergency medications such as auto-injectable epinephrine (EpiPens) for allergic reactions and bronchodilators for asthma and respiratory distress. It also establishes training, procedures, and reporting requirements for these emergency responses.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Students with allergies, asthma, or respiratory issues in public and nonpublic schools, school personnel, and families of affected students.
innovative_summary: The program employs a coordinated approach to emergency medication administration in schools, involving new training requirements, protocols, and collaboration between health and education departments, representing a significant technological and procedural advancement in school health safety.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has the potential to directly impact child poverty by improving health emergency responses in schools, thereby reducing the health and safety risks faced by vulnerable children, which can contribute to better educational and health outcomes.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Immediate Vesting
Synopsis: Providing that an individual serving as the State Superintendent of Schools shall immediately vest in the State Retirement and Pension System.
bill_summary: The bill grants immediate vesting rights in the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System to the State Superintendent of Schools upon taking office, meaning they automatically become fully vested in the retirement system.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: State Superintendent of Schools and relevant state employees
innovative_summary: The program employs a straightforward administrative change to retirement vesting rules, not employing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Low potential for direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Insurance - Hearing Representation
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Insurance Commissioner to allow corporations, partnerships, limited liability companies, and sole proprietorships that are small employers to be represented by certain authorized individuals rather than an attorney in certain hearings held by the Commissioner.
bill_summary: This bill allows small employer business entities to be represented by authorized individuals other than attorneys during certain insurance hearings held by the Maryland Insurance Commissioner.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commission
stakeholders: Small employer business entities, insurers, and the Maryland Insurance Commissioner
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new approach by allowing business entities to be represented by designated authorized personnel rather than necessarily by legal counsel, streamlining hearing processes for small businesses.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill potentially improves access to insurance regulatory processes for small employers, which may indirectly support economic stability but does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Resources and Education for All Prisons (REAP) Act
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to assist incarcerated individuals in accessing federal Pell Grants for higher education; requiring the Department to set goals for the number of incarcerated individuals in postsecondary education programs, establish tracking systems for their progress in postsecondary education programs, and forward certain data to the Maryland Higher Education Commission; requiring the Commission to assist the Department in establishing the tracking systems; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to help incarcerated individuals access federal Pell Grants for higher education, establish tracking systems for their participation and progress in postsecondary education programs, and coordinate with higher education institutions for program support.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals seeking higher education and related federal grants
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a systematic approach to enhance access to postsecondary education and implement tracking systems for incarcerated individuals, leveraging coordination between correctional services and higher education institutions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a potential moderate to high impact on child poverty by improving access to higher education for incarcerated individuals, which can lead to better economic outcomes post-release.

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Termination of Residential Lease - Limitation of Liability for Rent
Synopsis: Limiting a tenant's liability for rent to not more than 2 months' rent after the date on which the tenant vacates a leased premises if a physician or psychologist completes a form specifying that the tenant has a mental disorder, the management of which is substantially limited by the leased premises.
bill_summary: This bill limits a tenantâ€™s liability for rent after vacating a rental property if a physician, therapist, or psychologist certifies that the tenant has a certain disability or mental disorder that impacts their ability to live in the property.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Real Property or relevant housing authority
stakeholders: Tenants with disabilities or mental disorders, landlords, housing agencies
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a specific certification process by licensed medical or mental health professionals to limit tenant rent liability, integrating healthcare qualifications into housing law.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could help tenants with disabilities avoid excessive rent liabilities, potentially reducing financial hardship and poverty among vulnerable populations.

Title: Correctional Services - Inmate Employment - Agricultural Work
Synopsis: Repealing the authority of the Division of Correction to arrange for inmates not needed or being used by the State Highway Administration to perform emergency road work to be employed in agricultural work during any part of the year at a camp in Queen Anne's County or any other county with a similar camp.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the authority of the Division of Correction to employ inmates in agricultural work and related activities.
responsible_party: Division of Correction
stakeholders: Inmates in correctional facilities, farmers, and the Department of Correction
innovative_summary: The bill primarily changes existing legal authority; it does not introduce new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty.

Title: Health - Newborn Screening Program - Implementation of Testing
Synopsis: Repealing a certain requirement related to the inclusion of a core condition in the system for newborn screening; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to implement testing for a core condition listed in the Recommended Uniform Screening Panel within a certain time period after the core condition is added to the Panel; authorizing the Department to screen for any condition recommended by the Advisory Council and approved by the Secretary; requiring the Department to implement testing for Krabbe leukodystrophy at a certain time; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland's newborn screening system to include testing for Krabbe leukodystrophy and enhances the process for adding new conditions to the screening panel, with specific timelines and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Newborn infants and their families in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces proactive protocols and detailed reporting for the addition of screening conditions, emphasizing timely implementation and federal recommendations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on newborn health screening can help early detection and treatment, potentially reducing child health disparities and long-term poverty impacts.

Title: Baby Food - Toxic Heavy Metals - Testing and Labeling (Rudy's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning January 1, 2025, manufacturers of baby food to test a representative sample of each production aggregate of the manufacturer's final baby food product for certain toxic heavy metals; requiring, beginning January 1, 2026, manufacturers of baby food to make certain information related to the testing and a link to certain guidance available on the manufacturer's website; requiring a consumer to report to the Maryland Department of Health if the consumer believes that baby food is being sold with toxic heavy metals; etc.
bill_summary: The bill, known as Rudyâ€™s Law, mandates that baby food manufacturers test for toxic heavy metals (arsenic, cadmium, lead, mercury) before packaging, publish testing results online, and include QR codes on labels linking to this information. It aims to ensure baby food safety and improve transparency for consumers.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Baby food manufacturers, parents, and children in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs technology by requiring QR codes on baby food labels linked to testing results and safety information, increasing transparency and consumer knowledge.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program may indirectly impact child health and safety but does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Criminal Law â€“ Sexual Solicitation of a Minor Through Child Pornography â€“ Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting an individual from knowingly and with a certain intent soliciting a minor or law enforcement officer posing as a minor to engage in certain prohibited sexual acts with the minor by a certain means.
bill_summary: This bill enhances Maryland statutes related to the solicitation of minors through electronic means and the sexual exploitation of minors, including prohibiting soliciting minors or law enforcement posing as minors for unlawful sexual acts, with significant penalties including imprisonment and fines.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Minors, law enforcement agencies, and the general public concerned with child protection
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates existing laws and imposes stricter penalties without introducing new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly address child poverty but aims to protect minors from exploitation and abuse.

Title: Motor Vehicles - Motorcycles - Passenger Restrictions
Synopsis: Requiring a rear passenger on a motorcycle to be able to firmly position the passenger's feet on the footrests of the motorcycle, subject to an exception for permanent physical disability.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland motor vehicle laws to specify that a rear motorcycle passenger must be able to position their feet firmly on the footrests, unless they have a permanent physical disability.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Motorcycle riders and passengers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a specific passenger positioning requirement for motorcycle safety, which is a targeted safety regulation but does not employ new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on motorcycle passenger safety regulations and does not directly impact child poverty.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Dental Services - Coverage and Rate Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to study the feasibility of including removable full and partial dentures and setting adequate reimbursement rates for providers on a per-patient basis for house calls and extended care facility calls among the coverage offered by the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program; and requiring the Department to report its findings from the study to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee by December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to study the feasibility of expanding dental coverage under the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program to include full and partial dentures and provider reimbursement for house and extended care facility calls. It also requires setting reimbursement rates at no less than 60% of commercial rates or ADA benchmark charges, and reporting findings by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Low-income populations in Maryland needing dental care, dental providers, state health policymakers
innovative_summary: The program proposes a study to assess expanding dental coverage and payment rates, which is a strategic approach to improving oral health access but does not involve deploying new technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to improve dental access for low-income populations, which could help reduce child poverty related to health disparities.

Title: Drunk Driving Offenses - Expungement and the Ignition Interlock System Program
Synopsis: Authorizing a person to file a petition for expungement of certain records relating to a probation before judgment for driving while impaired or driving while under the influence; requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to require persons convicted of or granted probation before judgment for certain criminal offenses related to driving while impaired by alcohol, a drug, drug combination, or a combination of drugs and alcohol to participate in the Ignition Interlock System Program for certain periods of time; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes persons with certain drunk driving records to petition for expungement, and requires individuals convicted or granted probation for specific drunk driving offenses to participate in the Ignition Interlock System Program. It establishes reporting requirements for the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration about program participation.
responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration and the courts
stakeholders: Individuals convicted of or granted probation for drunk driving offenses in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a technology-based approach through the Ignition Interlock System Program to prevent drunk driving, combined with record expungement policies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty but improves public safety and legal processes.

Title: Baltimore County Board of Education - Nonstudent Member Compensation and Student Member Scholarships - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the annual compensation of certain nonstudent members of the Baltimore County Board of Education from $7,500 to $16,500; providing that the chair of the county board is entitled to receive $17,500 annually as compensation; and increasing the amount that a student member of the board is granted for a certain scholarship from $7,500 to $10,000.
bill_summary: The bill increases the annual compensation for nonstudent members of the Baltimore County Board of Education, establishes a specific compensation for the chair, and increases the scholarship amount for student members who complete a full term.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of Education
stakeholders: Members of the Baltimore County Board of Education and student members
innovative_summary: No, the bill mainly adjusts compensation and scholarship amounts, and does not establish new services or initiatives.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's changes to compensation and scholarships are unlikely to have a significant direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Natural Resources - Submerged Aquatic Vegetation - Alteration or Removal Requirements
Synopsis: Authorizing certain persons to alter certain submerged aquatic vegetation in a certain manner and in accordance with certain requirements; authorizing a public utility company or telecommunications carrier to alter certain submerged aquatic vegetation in a certain manner and in accordance with certain requirements; and altering certain requirements related to the alteration or removal of certain submerged aquatic vegetation.
bill_summary: The bill modifies regulations regarding the alteration and removal of submerged aquatic vegetation in Maryland's tidal waters, allowing certain entities to trim or harvest vegetation within specific limits without prior Department approval, and establishing requirements for permitting and best practices.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Maritime property owners, utility companies, telecommunications carriers, environmental agencies, and the general public using tidal waters
innovative_summary: The bill introduces streamlined procedures and specific allowances for vegetation management in tidal waters, emphasizing best practices and departmental oversight, employing regulatory adjustments rather than new technology-based solutions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited potential to directly impact child poverty, focusing mainly on environmental and waterway management.

Title: Persons Doing Public Business â€“ Disclosure Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring a person to file a registration statement with the State Board of Elections within a certain time period after the award of a contract that causes the person to be doing public business; requiring persons doing public business to update information on beneficial ownership included in the registration statement in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Board; altering the time at which a person doing public business is required to file a certain initial statement with the State Board; etc.
bill_summary: The bill enhances transparency by requiring persons doing public business with the state to disclose beneficial ownership information, file registration statements within 15 business days of winning a contract, and update this information as needed. It also requires governmental entities to verify compliance, potentially impose fees for late filings, and establishes reporting and penalty provisions.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and Maryland Secretary of State
stakeholders: Businesses engaging in public contracts and state agencies
innovative_summary: The program employs comprehensive disclosure and registration requirements with timely reporting, updates, and enforcement mechanisms to improve transparency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill may indirectly impact child poverty by promoting transparency and integrity in public contracting, which can lead to better resource allocation and public trust.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Horse Riding - Helmet Requirement for Minors
Synopsis: Prohibiting an adult from allowing certain minors to ride a horse, donkey, mule, or pony on a highway, a public horse-riding path, or the grounds of a facility for which the primary purpose is recreational, educational, therapeutic, or competitive equestrian activities unless the minor is wearing a properly secured helmet that meets or exceeds the standards of the American Society of Testing and Materials for protective headgear used in equestrian riding.
bill_summary: The bill requires that minors riding horses on certain property must wear helmets that meet specific safety standards, and prohibits adults from allowing minors to ride without such helmets on designated properties.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation or relevant local authorities responsible for enforcing horseback riding safety
stakeholders: Minors who ride horses, horse riding instructors, parents, and guardians
innovative_summary: The bill introduces helmet safety requirements for minors in a recreational activity, employing safety standards and legal enforcement to enhance rider protection.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly focuses on safety regulations rather than economic support.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Victims' Rights - Notification of Release From Confinement (Jaycee Webster Victims' Rights Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a certain commitment unit to include in a notification given to a victim, victim's representative, or witness regarding the release from confinement of a sentenced defendant or child respondent the telephone number of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center.
bill_summary: The bill requires certain commitment units to notify victims, witnesses, or their representatives about the release from confinement of a defendant or child respondent, including providing the contact information of a specific victim services employee.
responsible_party: Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center and commitment units within the criminal justice system
stakeholders: Victims, witnesses, victims' representatives, and defendants or child respondents involved in criminal cases in Maryland
innovative_summary: This bill enhances victim and witness notification procedures by including specific contact information for victim services in release notifications.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill likely has minimal direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Department of Natural Resources - Maryland Geological Survey Fund - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Geological Survey Fund to finance certain direct and indirect costs, including long-term budgeting and planning for survey projects, procurements, and equipment purchases; establishing the Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund in the Department of Natural Resources; and requiring interest earnings of the Fund to be credited to the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Geological Survey Fund as a special nonlapsing fund within the Department of Natural Resources to finance geological survey activities, including mapping, assessments, and equipment purchases.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Geologists, researchers, public agencies, and citizens interested in Maryland's geology and natural resources
innovative_summary: The bill creates a dedicated fund for geological surveys with clear allocations for operational costs and investments, employing standard government funding approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has no direct impact on child poverty, focusing instead on geological research infrastructure.

Title: Public Health - Giving Infants a Future Without Transmission (GIFT) Act
Synopsis: Altering certain HIV and syphilis reporting and testing requirements for hospitals and health care providers for pregnant women and newborns; providing that certain documents related to certain HIV and syphilis reports are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any criminal or administrative action; and altering certain penalties related to the disclosure of personal identifying health information acquired for the purpose of HIV and AIDS reporting under certain provisions of law.
bill_summary: The bill updates HIV and syphilis testing, reporting, and confidentiality requirements for healthcare providers and institutions. It emphasizes confidentiality, streamlines reporting procedures, and enhances patient rights and provider responsibilities for pregnant women and newborns.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Pregnant women, newborns, healthcare providers, hospitals, and public health agencies
innovative_summary: The bill introduces modernized, integrated protocols for HIV and syphilis testing and reporting, with a focus on confidentiality and patient rights, employing current health data standards.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but improves health screening and confidentiality for vulnerable populations.

Title: Economic Development - Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation - Loans
Synopsis: Altering a certain loan program to authorize the Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation to provide loans of up to $10,000 for each seasonal full-time job; expanding eligibility for the Maryland Watermen's Microloan Program within the Corporation to include, starting July 1, 2025, individuals who are residents of the State and hold a commercial fishing license to catch finfish, crabs, clams, or oysters issued by the Potomac River Fisheries Commission; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the Maryland Watermenâ€™s Microloan Program to expand eligibility to include residents with certain commercial fishing licenses and increases the program's funding. It also introduces provisions for loans to assist commercial fishermen, including beginner and generational watermen, and adjusts reporting and loan forgiveness rules.
responsible_party: Maryland Agricultural and Resourceâ€“Based Industry Development Corporation
stakeholders: Commercial fishermen, watermen, seafood processing businesses, residents with fishing licenses
innovative_summary: The program employs microloans and targeted eligibility enhancements to support traditional fishing communities and incorporate new participants, utilizing financial tools and license-based eligibility.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Potential for a positive impact on child poverty through supporting family-based fishing businesses and sustaining employment in fishing communities.

Title: Division of Parole and Probation - Criteria for Earned Compliance Credit - Exception for Supervision Fees
Synopsis: Altering a certain condition regarding the payment of certain restitution, fines, and fees that a certain supervised individual must satisfy to accrue certain earned compliance credit while under the supervision of the Division of Parole and Probation in the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the criteria for earning compliance credits for individuals on supervised release and adjusts fee collection requirements for parole and probation supervision in Maryland.
responsible_party: Division of Parole and Probation in the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals under supervision of parole and probation, and the Maryland justice system
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new criterion for earning compliance credits related to current payments of restitution, fines, and fees, but does not involve new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it primarily affects supervision policies and fee collection.

Title: Courts â€“ Military Records â€“ Recordation and Inspection
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions of law relating to the recordation and inspection of certain military records kept by the clerk of a circuit court to authorize the clerk to keep an electronic record instead of a book to record and index the discharge papers of a person who has served in the uniformed services of the United States; and requiring the clerk to deny inspection of the electronic record except under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill alters laws relating to the recordation and inspection of military discharge papers kept by the circuit court clerk, including provisions about who can access the records and the redaction of Social Security numbers.
responsible_party: Circuit Court Clerks in Maryland
stakeholders: Military veterans and their families, legal professionals, and government agencies involved in matters related to military discharge records.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates existing procedures for access and privacy protections regarding military records; it does not introduce new technology or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty.

Title: Public Health - Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program to authorize pharmacists to dispense nPEP under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to adopt regulations necessary for the administration of the Program and that address the needs of certain populations, including victims of sexual assault and pediatric patients; and authorizing the Department to administer the Program, collect certain fees, and establish guidelines for training related to the Program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program, allowing pharmacists and certain healthcare providers to dispense nPEP medications without a prescription under certain guidelines, with the Maryland Department of Health overseeing the program.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals at risk of HIV exposure, healthcare providers, pharmacists, public health agencies
innovative_summary: The program employs new approaches by allowing pharmacists to dispense HIV prevention medication under standing orders, guided by specific regulations and training, expanding access to HIV prophylaxis.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's impact on child poverty is indirect and minimal, as it focuses mainly on HIV prevention and public health.

Title: Housing Development Permit Applications - Local Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring local jurisdictions with at least 150,000 residents to report certain information for each building or development permit application that includes a residential housing component as part of the development to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Planning on or before July 1 each year; and requiring a local jurisdiction to make a copy of the report publicly available on its website.
bill_summary: The bill requires large Maryland local jurisdictions (populations of at least 150,000 residents) to annually report detailed data on building and development permit applications that include residential housing components and make this information publicly accessible, aiding transparency and planning.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Planning
stakeholders: Residents, local governments, developers, housing advocates
innovative_summary: The program employs transparency through mandatory reporting and public accessibility of development data to inform public and policy responses.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's emphasis on residential development reporting and transparency can indirectly support efforts to address child poverty by promoting affordable housing development.

Title: Employment Standards, Prevailing Wage, and Living Wage - Employer Adverse Actions and Enforcement
Synopsis: Prohibiting employers from taking or threatening to take adverse action against an employee because the employee takes certain actions regarding rights and responsibilities, complaints, investigations, proceedings, or hearings; authorizing the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, within 90 days after receipt of a written complaint, to investigate a violation and attempt to resolve the issue informally through mediation; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits employers from retaliating against employees for exercising their rights under specific employment laws, such as making complaints or cooperating with investigations, and establishes procedures for enforcement and penalties for violations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Employees and employers subject to employment laws in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill enhances enforcement mechanisms and protections against employer retaliation, including investigation powers and penalties, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on employment protections can indirectly benefit low-income families and children by improving job security and reducing economic hardship, but it does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Civil Actions - Civil Immunity - Educator Intervention
Synopsis: Providing that a member of the administrative, educational, or support staff of any public, private, or parochial school, acting in an official capacity, is not civilly liable for personal injury or property damage resulting from intervention in a student altercation or other student disturbance if the staff member intervened in a reasonably prudent manner and the actions taken do not constitute grossly negligent, willful, wanton, or intentionally tortious conduct.
