bill_summary: This bill amends record-keeping requirements for junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and automotive dismantlers/recyclers in Maryland, requiring detailed information about vehicles and catalytic converters obtained from individuals.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation and the Maryland Business Regulation authorities
stakeholders: Junk dealers, scrap metal processors, automotive recyclers, and the general public concerned with vehicle and scrap metal transactions
innovative_summary: The bill enhances traceability and accountability in the scrap metal and vehicle dismantling industries through detailed record-keeping, with some technological integration in record management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not explicitly target child poverty but potentially improves public safety and industry regulation.

Title: Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program â€“ Alterations
Synopsis: Expanding eligibility for financial assistance under the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program to include individuals who purchase certain qualified property after a qualified project is completed, at an affordable sales price as determined by certain regulations, and as an owner-occupant.
bill_summary: The bill expands the eligibility for the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program to include individuals purchasing qualified property as owner-occupants, in addition to developers.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Individuals purchasing or developing affordable housing in low-income and historically redlined neighborhoods
innovative_summary: The program employs financial assistance to close appraisal gaps in neighborhoods affected by historic redlining, supporting homeownership for residents.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential to directly reduce child poverty by promoting homeownership opportunities in underserved communities.

Title: State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators - Requirements for Assisted Living Managers
Synopsis: Extending, from October 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026, the date by which an individual must be licensed by the State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators before practicing as an assisted living manager in the State; altering the requirements for the manager training course that certain assisted living managers are required to complete; altering the requirements for serving as an interim assisted living manager; and requiring the Board to submit certain reports on assisted living managers to certain committees of the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill extends the deadline for assisted living managers in Maryland to become licensed, modifies requirements for manager training courses and interim service, and establishes licensure rules for assisted living managers, including a phased implementation and reporting obligations for the licensing board.
responsible_party: State Board of Longâ€“Term Care Administrators
stakeholders: Assisted living managers, assisted living facilities, residents of assisted living facilities in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates licensing requirements for assisted living managers and implements phased enforcement and reporting, but does not introduce new technologies or particularly innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program may indirectly impact child poverty if it improves care quality and stability in assisted living facilities, but the direct impact is limited.

Title: Board of Public Works - Transparency Data Dashboard
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller to develop and maintain on the Board of Public Works' website a procurement transparency data dashboard; establishing a governance committee composed of the liaisons to the Board from the offices of the Governor, the Comptroller, and the State Treasurer to review the contents of the dashboard for accuracy and completeness; and requiring the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2025, to include in the annual budget bill such sums as are necessary for one full-time position and data dashboard development software.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Board of Public Works to have a transparent, public, interactive procurement data dashboard on its website, developed and maintained by the Comptroller, which includes information on meetings, contracts, and procurement programs.
responsible_party: Board of Public Works and the Comptroller's Office
stakeholders: State procurement entities, vendors, and the general public interested in state procurement processes
innovative_summary: The bill promotes transparency and uses interactive, searchable online dashboards to display procurement data, potentially integrating with existing payment portals.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on transparency in procurement could indirectly improve conditions for vulnerable populations by increasing accountability and fair access to state contracts.

Title: Business Regulation - Sale of Motor Fuel - Pricing Signage (Gas Price Clarity Act)
Synopsis: Establishing that certain provisions governing signage at retail service stations supersede inconsistent local law; altering a signage requirement for retail service stations relating to the price of regular gasoline so that the signage prominently displays clearly and visibly the credit and debit price, if higher than the cash price, or the credit and debit price and the cash price; repealing an exemption from a certain signage requirement for retail service station dealers with not more than 3 dispensing units; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates signage requirements for retail fuel stations in Maryland, including display of fuel prices, taxes, and fuel grade designations, and clarifies the supremacy of state signage laws over local laws.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of the Comptroller
stakeholders: Retail fuel stations, motorists, and consumers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill primarily standardizes and clarifies existing signage requirements, with no significant use of new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly concerns signage regulations at fuel stations.

Title: Maryland Department of Health - Health Commissions and Maryland Insurance Administration - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to contract with an independent consultant to conduct a certain study of the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the Maryland Health Care Commission, the Maryland Insurance Administration, and the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission; and requiring the Department to submit a report on the results of the study to the Governor, the Senate Finance Committee, and the House Health and Government Operations Committee on or before January 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to commission a study of various state health commissions and the Maryland Insurance Administration to examine their duties, overlap, efficiencies, and potential structural improvements, with a final report due by January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Marylanders affected by health and insurance regulation, state health agencies, and the general public
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive analysis and review process to streamline and improve the effectiveness of state health agencies, incorporating input from multiple agencies and an independent consultant.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is indirect and does not specifically target child poverty but aims to improve healthcare and insurance services, which could benefit vulnerable populations including children.

Title: Corporations and Associations - Ratification of Defective Corporate Acts - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the process by which a defective corporate act may be ratified; and altering rules for certain legal actions by persons claiming to be adversely affected by a ratification.
bill_summary: This bill reforms the process by which corporations in Maryland can ratify and validate defective corporate acts, including acts involving overissuance or improper stock issuance, to ensure they are considered valid if properly ratified.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce or Maryland Secretary of State (not explicitly specified)
stakeholders: Maryland corporations and their shareholders, and the legal system handling corporate disputes
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a formalized legal process for ratifying defective corporate acts, including online or public disclosures where applicable, but generally follows existing legal principles.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Maryland Tort Claims Act - Sheriffs and Deputy Sheriffs - County Responsibility
Synopsis: Clarifying that a county assumes the responsibilities of a certain tort claim against a sheriff or deputy sheriff under the Maryland Tort Claims Act; clarifying that, for certain tort claims against a sheriff or deputy sheriff, the State is the proper defendant; and specifying that it is the intent of the General Assembly that the Office of the Attorney General and the State Treasurer work with certain entities when disputes arise regarding the allocation of responsibility for tort claims under the Act.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies that counties are responsible for tort claims against sheriffs and deputy sheriffs related to law enforcement and detention center functions, specifies that the State is the proper defendant in such claims, and outlines how disputes regarding responsibility should be handled collaboratively. It also updates related liability limits and enforcement provisions.
responsible_party: Maryland counties and the Maryland Attorney General's Office
stakeholders: Sheriffs, deputy sheriffs, counties, and residents affected by law enforcement and detention center activities
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modifies legal responsibilities, liability limits, and procedural arrangements for tort claims involving law enforcement activities, rather than creating new services or initiatives.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty but may influence law enforcement operations and liability in contexts impacting children.

Title: Higher Education - Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship to make the scholarship applicable to all programs at institutions of higher education in the State; altering the maximum award available, when a scholarship should be credited, and to whom initial awards should be provided under the scholarship; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship to apply to all courses at Maryland higher education institutions, increases the maximum award amount, and establishes the Maryland Loan Repayment Assistance Program for firefighters and emergency medical services providers, including provisions for evaluation and administration.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission and Office of the Governor
stakeholders: Firefighters, emergency medical services providers, fire and rescue squads, and higher education students in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a coordinated approach combining scholarships and loan repayment assistance specifically targeted at fire and emergency medical personnel, utilizing educational incentives and new evaluation efforts.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has moderate potential for direct impact on child poverty by supporting emergency personnel recruitment and retention, which can improve community safety and services.

Title: Higher Education - Part-Time Senatorial and Delegate Scholarships - Alterations
Synopsis: Allowing an applicant of a part-time senatorial or delegate scholarship with a documented disability to request from the Maryland Higher Education Commission a waiver from the requirement to carry at least 6 semester hours of courses each semester.
bill_summary: The bill allows applicants for part-time senatorial or delegate scholarships with a documented disability to request a waiver of the semester hour requirements during the application process.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Students with disabilities seeking scholarships for higher education in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a flexible waiver process for scholarship requirements for students with disabilities, adapting existing scholarship rules to be more inclusive.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has the potential to reduce barriers to higher education for students with disabilities, possibly impacting child poverty indirectly.

Title: Prekindergarten - Ulysses Currie Head Start Program - Eligibility for State Funds
Synopsis: Authorizing a provider in the Ulysses Currie Head Start Program to receive certain State funds under certain circumstances; and exempting providers in the Program from certain State requirements for eligible prekindergarten providers.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes providers in the Ulysses Currie Head Start Program to receive full state funding regardless of federal funding received, allocates at least $3 million annually for the program, and establishes new structural quality standards for prekindergarten providers starting in the 2027-2028 school year. It also exempts Head Start providers from certain requirements and sets guidelines for program quality ratings, religious activity restrictions, and nondiscrimination policies.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education
stakeholders: Prekindergarten children, families, educators, and early childhood providers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill incorporates evidence-based and nationally recognized standards for prekindergarten programs, emphasizes program quality through Maryland EXCELS ratings, and aligns Head Start program funding and standards with state initiatives, representing an integrated approach to early childhood education quality improvement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to impact child poverty by improving early childhood education access and quality for vulnerable children.

Title: Education - Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program and Fund - Established
Synopsis: Requiring certain information to be provided to the parents of a child with a disability under certain circumstances; establishing the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program; establishing the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Fund; requiring interest earnings of the Fund to be credited to the Fund; requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $1,000,000 to the Fund beginning in fiscal year 2026; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program and Fund in Maryland, aimed at providing legal, advocacy, and consulting services to eligible students with disabilities and their families, especially those with limited income.
responsible_party: Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service
stakeholders: Students with disabilities and their families, especially those with limited income, and public education agencies in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program introduces a dedicated fund and structured support services utilizing trained advocates, consultants, and lawyers to improve access to legal and advocacy support in special education cases, employing new structured funding and oversight mechanisms.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly reduce child poverty by increasing access to legal and advocacy resources for low-income families navigating special education needs.

Title: Garrett County â€“ Sheriffâ€™s Salary â€“ Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the salary of the Sheriff of Garrett County; and repealing the requirement for the Garrett County Salary Study Commission to study and issue a report that contains recommendations relating to the salary of the Sheriff.
bill_summary: The bill changes the salary structure for the Sheriff of Garrett County, making it 80% of the County's State's Attorney's salary, and repeals the existing salary study commission requirement.
responsible_party: Garrett County government (County Commissioners)
stakeholders: Sheriff of Garrett County, Garrett County residents, County government employees
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modifies salary setting rules and removes the salary study commission, which is a traditional administrative procedure, thus not employing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited potential to directly impact child poverty as it mainly concerns sheriff salary adjustments.

Title: Garrett County - Procurement - Bids and Contracts
Synopsis: Increasing the minimum dollar amount of contracts for which the County Commissioners, or any employee of Garrett County, are required to advertise for bids from $25,000 to $50,000; exempting certain contracts for professional services from a requirement to advertise for bids; and authorizing contracts for professional services required to be licensed by the State to be solicited by written bids.
bill_summary: The bill increases the minimum contract amount requiring Garrett County to advertise for bids from $25,000 to $50,000, and updates related procurement rules.
responsible_party: Garrett County Government
stakeholders: Garrett County residents and local government officials involved in procurement
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates existing procurement procedures with modest financial thresholds; it does not introduce new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program - Modifications
Synopsis: Altering procedures for the claiming and awarding of grants under the Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program to allow an individual or corporation who paid or incurred qualified capital expenses during the immediately preceding calendar year to submit a grant application.
bill_summary: The bill modifies procedures for the Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program, including application and award processes, to ensure proper allocation of grants for qualified expenses paid or incurred in the previous year.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Wineries and vineyards in Maryland seeking economic development grants
innovative_summary: The bill primarily adjusts existing grant procedures and does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: State Treasurer and Comptroller - Membership Responsibilities
Synopsis: Removing the State Treasurer from the Board of Trustees for the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation and repealing related authority and duties; removing the State Treasurer or the State Treasurer's designee from the Maryland Commission on Climate Change and the Coast Smart Council; and adding the Comptroller or the Comptroller's designee as a member of the Maryland Commission on Climate Change and the Coast Smart Council.
bill_summary: The bill revises membership responsibilities of the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation, the Commission on Climate Change, the Maryland Environmental Service, and the Coast Smart Council by removing the State Treasurer from certain boards and committees and adding the Comptroller as a member. It also updates related provisions and organization rules.
responsible_party: Maryland State Departments of Agriculture, Environment, Natural Resources, and other overseeing agencies.
stakeholders: Maryland landowners, environmental agencies, local governments, and residents concerned with climate change and land preservation.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces organizational and membership structure changes to existing environmental and land preservation agencies, with a focus on governance and collaboration, but does not employ new technologies or novel approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on organizational governance and environmental initiatives, with indirect potential to support community resilience and land conservation, but it does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Washington County - Alcoholic Beverages - Multi-Use Sports and Events Facility Beer, Wine, and Liquor License
Synopsis: Altering the stadium beer and wine license in Washington County to be a multi-use sports and events facility beer, wine, and liquor license; authorizing the license holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption in the multi-use sports and events facility; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the existing stadium beer and wine license in Washington County to a multi-use sports and events facility license, allowing the sale of beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption at a broader range of events and locations within the facility.
responsible_party: Washington County Alcohol Beverage Board
stakeholders: Professional sports teams, event attendees, local residents, and businesses within the multi-use sports and events facility
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes alcohol licensing by expanding the scope of sale permissions at sports and events venues, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily modifies alcohol licensing regulations.

Title: Maryland Building Performance Standards â€“ Local Requests for Guidance â€“ Religious Considerations
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Labor, on request of a local jurisdiction and in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General, to provide guidance for the implementation and enforcement of the Maryland Building Performance Standards in relation to any religious observance, practice, or belief.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to provide guidance to local jurisdictions on implementing and enforcing the Maryland Building Performance Standards (MBPS) in a way that respects religious observances, practices, or beliefs upon request.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Local jurisdictions, religious communities, building officials
innovative_summary: The program introduces a new guidance process for integrating religious considerations into building standards, emphasizing collaborative and consultative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly target child poverty but aims to improve building standards inclusively.

Title: Washington County - Procurement - Vehicles
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Washington County to enter into a certain contract for the purchase of one or more vehicles without advertising for bids if the amount involved in the contract does not exceed $100,000.
bill_summary: The bill allows Washington County to purchase one or more vehicles without advertising for bids if the amount does not exceed $100,000.
responsible_party: Washington County Commissioners or their designated employees
stakeholders: Washington County residents and government officials involved in procurement
innovative_summary: The bill makes a minor adjustment to procurement rules, streamlining vehicle purchases by increasing the bidding threshold.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Agriculture â€“ Nuisance Insects
Synopsis: Requiring, instead of authorizing, the Secretary of Agriculture to implement, under certain circumstances, a program to use Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis to control or eliminate nuisance insects in the State; and requiring, instead of authorizing, the Secretary to carry out a certain project to control or eliminate nuisance insects if the county or municipality in which the nuisance insects are located agrees to pay 50% of the costs associated with the project.
bill_summary: The bill mandates the Maryland Secretary of Agriculture to implement a program using Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis to control nuisance insects, particularly black flies, on state, local government, and private properties with consent. It also requires local governments to contribute 50% of the program costs if they request it.
responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of Agriculture
stakeholders: Residents, local governments, and visitors affected by nuisance insects and insect control measures
innovative_summary: The program employs biological pesticides and involves coordinated spray operations with public notification and monitoring, applying new approaches to nuisance insect control.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to reduce nuisance insects that can affect public health and enjoyment of recreational areas, potentially improving community well-being.

Title: Health Insurance - Utilization Review - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering and establishing requirements and prohibitions related to health insurance utilization review; altering requirements related to internal grievance procedures and adverse decision procedures; altering certain reporting requirements on health insurance carriers relating to adverse decisions; and establishing requirements on health insurance carriers and health care providers relating to the provision of patient benefit information.
bill_summary: The bill establishes new requirements for health insurance utilization review processes in Maryland, including the implementation of online systems for electronic prior authorization, real-time benefit information, and improved grievance and adverse decision procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration and Maryland Health Care Commission
stakeholders: Health care providers, insurers, and Maryland residents with health insurance coverage
innovative_summary: The bill employs advanced technology by requiring online portals linking electronic health records, real-time benefit information, and electronic prior authorization processes, promoting transparency and efficiency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Moderate potential for impact, as improved healthcare authorization and information can aid vulnerable populations by reducing delays in care.

Title: Behavioral Health Crisis Response Services - 9-8-8 Trust Fund Fees
Synopsis: Establishing a 9-8-8 fee to be paid by each subscriber to switched local exchange access service, commercial mobile radio service, or other 9-8-8-accessible service; establishing a prepaid wireless 9-8-8 fee to be paid on certain retail transactions; requiring the Comptroller to deposit the 9-8-8 fees and the prepaid wireless 9-8-8 fees in the 9-8-8 Trust Fund; and requiring the Comptroller to adopt procedures for auditing fee collection and remittance by telephone companies and commercial mobile radio service providers.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a 9-8-8 trust fund funded by fees collected from telephone and wireless service providers to support behavioral health crisis response services, including crisis call centers, mobile crisis teams, and stabilization centers in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals needing mental health crisis services and the general public in Maryland
innovative_summary: The program employs a dedicated fund financed through a new, targeted fee on telephone and wireless services to support behavioral health crisis services, integrating mental health crisis response into existing telecommunications infrastructure.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could have a moderate direct impact on child poverty by improving access to mental health crisis services that benefit children and families.

Title: State Board of Physicians - Performance of X-Ray Duties Without a License
Synopsis: Altering the circumstances under which individuals without a license to practice medicine may perform X-ray duties; authorizing the State Board of Physicians to impose a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each violation on the physician's office and $1,000 for each individual violation of the Act; and requiring the Board, by October 1, 2029, to report to certain committees of the General Assembly on the number of individuals registered to perform limited X-ray duties and the continuation or replacement of the registration process.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a licensing and regulatory system for limited licensed radiologic technologists, allowing certain unlicensed individuals to perform specific X-ray duties under supervision and setting rules for their qualifications, registration, and oversight. It also creates an advisory committee and mandates a report on the program's progress after five years.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Physicians
stakeholders: Individuals seeking limited licensure in radiologic technology, healthcare providers, and patients in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs a mixed approach of licensing, supervision, and evaluation, leveraging regulatory oversight for a specialized workforce in radiologic procedures.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could have a moderate positive impact on child poverty by expanding workforce capacity and access to diagnostic services in healthcare settings.

Title: Stateâ€“Owned Nursing Homes â€“ Deficiencies, Citations, and Fines â€“ Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the department charged with oversight of a State-owned nursing home operated by a contractor, instead of the contractor, to provide notice of certain deficiencies and enforcement actions to the Governor and certain members of the General Assembly; requiring the department charged with oversight, rather than the contractor, to provide certain information to certain persons within 30 days after the contractor's final acceptance of a plan of correction or completion of an informal dispute resolution; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies reporting requirements for deficiencies, citations, and enforcement actions at State-owned nursing homes operated by contractors. It designates the Maryland Department of Labor as the oversight agency responsible for notification and reporting, details timelines for notices and reports, and mandates annual reporting to the Governor and General Assembly.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Residents and staff of State-owned nursing homes, government oversight agencies, families of residents
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency and accountability in State-owned nursing homes by instituting clear reporting timelines and designated oversight responsibilities, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited potential to directly impact child poverty as it mainly focuses on regulatory reporting for nursing homes.

Title: Education - Initial Teacher Certification - Requirements
Synopsis: Repealing a provision of law that requires a teacher preparation program to require a student to pass a certain assessment as a graduation requirement; altering the requirements for initial teacher certification; authorizing a local school system to establish a comprehensive induction program to aid in meeting a certain requirement for initial teacher certification; altering the qualification requirements for a teacher who holds a professional license or certificate from another state; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the requirements and assessments for initial teacher certification in Maryland, including removing certain testing requirements, establishing new assessments, and creating comprehensive induction programs. It also facilitates reciprocity agreements with other states for teacher certification.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Teachers seeking initial certification, teacher preparation programs, students, and local school systems
innovative_summary: The bill employs new assessment standards and locally developed induction programs, incorporating diversity and digital learning components, and enhances reciprocity agreements with other states.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has potential for high impact on child poverty by increasing qualified teachers and supporting diversity in education.

Title: Civil Actions - Public Nuisances - Firearm Industry Members (Gun Industry Accountability Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Prohibiting firearm industry members from knowingly creating, maintaining, or contributing to a public nuisance through the sale, manufacture, distribution, importation, or marketing of a firearm-related product under certain circumstances; requiring a firearm industry member to establish and implement certain reasonable controls regarding the sale, manufacture, distribution, importation, marketing, possession, and use of certain firearm-related products; authorizing certain civil actions for violations of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: The bill creates civil action provisions allowing the Maryland Attorney General, county attorneys, or Baltimore City Solicitor to file lawsuits against firearm industry members for engaging in conduct that knowingly harms the public through the sale, manufacture, importation, or marketing of firearms or related products, if they violate certain reasonable controls and contribute to public nuisance.
responsible_party: Attorney General of Maryland and local attorneys
stakeholders: Firearm industry members, public, local and state authorities, victims of firearm-related harm
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a civil nuisance framework specifically targeting firearm industry conduct, with legal actions that include injunctive relief, damages, and require establishing controls; this approach emphasizes accountability through civil litigation within the context of public nuisance law.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a potential to reduce harm from firearms, which could contribute to lowering child poverty through increased public safety, though it is indirect.

Title: Maryland Transit Administration - Locally Operated Transit Systems - Mandatory Funding
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning in fiscal year 2026, the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation from the Transportation Trust Fund of $80,533,314 for the Locally Operated Transit System Grant Program.
bill_summary: This bill mandates the Maryland Governor to allocate at least $80,533,314 annually from the Transportation Trust Fund to the Locally Operated Transit System Grant Program starting in fiscal year 2026 and thereafter, to support statewide transit operations.
responsible_party: Maryland State Government, specifically the Maryland Transit Administration
stakeholders: Residents and users of locally operated transit systems in Maryland, including public transit riders and local transit agencies
innovative_summary: The bill primarily establishes a consistent, legally mandated funding stream for local transit systems, improving financial stability and operational support without employing new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it mainly provides funding for transit operations, which can indirectly improve access to education and employment opportunities for low-income families.

Title: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange - State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program - Amount of Annual Subsidies
Synopsis: Altering the amount of funds the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is authorized to designate for annual subsidies under the State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program for certain fiscal years to include unspent funds designated for subsidies for young adults in a previous calendar year.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the funding rules for the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange's Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program, allowing unspent funds from previous years to be carried over and used for future subsidies, and increases the maximum annual subsidy amount.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
stakeholders: Young adults aged 18 to 40 with income between 133% and 400% of the federal poverty level
innovative_summary: The program employs a flexible funding approach by allowing unspent funds to be carried over to future years, which is a moderate innovation in program funding management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could have a significant impact on child poverty reduction by increasing healthcare access for young adults in low- to middle-income levels.

Title: Health Occupations - Certified Dialysis Technicians - Continuing Education Requirement
Synopsis: Altering the continuing education requirement for certified dialysis technicians to complete 3 hours of continuing education approved by the Board.
bill_summary: The bill changes the continuing education requirements for certified dialysis technicians in Maryland, including the number of hours required and the date the new rules take effect.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Nursing or relevant state health occupational board
stakeholders: Certified dialysis technicians and patients receiving dialysis
innovative_summary: The bill mainly updates existing requirements and does not introduce new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty.

Title: City of Frederick - Assignment of Offenders to Road Work - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing a provision of law requring a District Court judge to assign, if practicable, an offender to work the public roads of Frederick County or the City of Frederick as a penalty for a violation of a municipal law or ordinance of the City of Frederick.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the existing law that assigned offenders guilty of violating municipal laws or ordinances in Frederick to work on public roads, effectively ending this form of community service for such offenders.
responsible_party: City of Frederick and Frederick County courts, law enforcement, and municipal authorities.
stakeholders: Offenders in Frederick who would have been assigned to work on public roads, municipal authorities, law enforcement, and residents of Frederick County.
innovative_summary: The bill removes a traditional community service program rather than introducing new technology or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty since it mainly affects local punitive practices.

Title: State Procurement - Small Business Reserve Program - Goals and Outreach Program
Synopsis: Increasing a participation goal from a minimum of 15% to 20% for certain small businesses for certain procurement contracts; requiring the certification agency, in consultation with Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to develop an outreach program to increase the participation of small businesses that are owned by economically disadvantaged individuals; requiring, by each December 1, the certification agency to submit a report on the outreach program and the dollar amount of certain awards; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Small and Minority Business Reserve Program in Maryland, setting procurement goals, establishing outreach and certification standards, and requiring a study to evaluate program compliance with legal requirements. It aims to increase participation of small and minority-owned businesses in state contracts.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs and the Department of General Services
stakeholders: Small businesses, minority business enterprises, economically disadvantaged individuals, and state agencies involved in procurement
innovative_summary: The bill employs a structured approach including standards, outreach, and evaluations for increasing minority and small business participation in government procurement, with a focus on compliance and reporting.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has moderate potential to impact child poverty by supporting economically disadvantaged individuals through increased business opportunities.

Title: Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System - Reemployment as Sheriff
Synopsis: Requiring the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System to suspend the retirement benefit of a retiree of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System who is elected as a sheriff within 1 year after retirement; providing for the reinstatement of a benefit; providing that a suspension of a benefit does not affect survivor benefits; and applying the Act prospectively.
bill_summary: The bill allows retirees of the Maryland Law Enforcement Officersâ€™ Pension System to be temporarily suspended from receiving their pension benefits if they are elected as a sheriff within a specified period after retirement. Once they cease serving as a sheriff, their benefits are reinstated with any cost-of-living adjustments.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pensions System
stakeholders: Retirees of the Law Enforcement Officersâ€™ Pension System, future and current law enforcement officers, and the public they serve.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a specific mechanism to suspend and reinstate pension benefits based on employment as a sheriff, which is a targeted administrative adjustment rather than a new technology or approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty, focusing primarily on pension administration for law enforcement retirees.

Title: Town of Keedysville - Parking of Vehicles - Restrictions
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from parking certain vehicles in the Town of Keedysville, Washington County.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits parking certain vehicles in the Town of Keedysville and specifies conditions under which vehicles can be parked on streets or highways, including the types of vehicles affected and exceptions for immediate use.
responsible_party: Town of Keedysville local government or Washington County authorities
stakeholders: Residents and visitors of Keedysville, vehicle owners of designated vehicle types
innovative_summary: The bill employs traditional parking regulations without introducing new technologies or novel approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has no direct impact on child poverty as it primarily involves parking regulations for certain vehicle types.

Title: Death Certificates - Cause or Manner of Death Determinations - Requirements After Change or Correction (Katherine Morris Death Reclassification Act)
Synopsis: Requiring, if a victim's initial determination of death recorded on the victim's death certificate was amended or corrected to be undetermined or homicide, an assistant State's Attorney with knowledge of the case to meet with a person in interest on the request of the person in interest for a certain purpose; requiring a law enforcement agency to reopen or reinvestigate an investigation involving the death of a victim whose cause or manner of death was amended or corrected to be undetermined or homicide; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes procedures for reviewing and potentially reopening investigations when a victim's cause or manner of death on their death certificate is amended to 'undetermined' or 'homicide'. It requires meetings with interested persons, notifications to law enforcement, and sets a 20-year extension on case investigations.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of the State's Attorney, Medical Examiner's Office, and Law Enforcement Agencies
stakeholders: Victims' families, law enforcement, medical examiners, and the general public
innovative_summary: The program introduces a structured legal and investigative process for reevaluating certain death cases, emphasizing transparency and long-term investigation protocols, which is a new approach in death case management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily impacts death investigation protocols and law enforcement processes, with no direct link to child poverty outcomes.

Title: Washington County - Interscholastic Athletics - Student Eligibility Waiver and School Classification
Synopsis: Authorizing the Washington County Board of Education to waive a certain eligibility requirement for participation in interscholastic athletics at a certain Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association member school for students who attend certain public high schools; requiring the Washington County Superintendent of Schools to report to the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association the school enrollment of member schools in grades 9, 10, and 11 as of September 30 of each even-numbered year; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Washington County Board of Education to waive certain eligibility requirements for students to participate in interscholastic athletics, specifically allowing students attending non-zoned high schools that lack athletics programs to participate at their zoned high school. It also requires reporting on school enrollments for athletic classifications.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of Education
stakeholders: Students in Washington County public high schools, particularly those attending non-zoned schools without athletic programs
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a tailored eligibility waiver process and requires reporting of actual school enrollment for athletic classifications, incorporating data sharing and flexible participation policies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Moderate potential to impact child poverty by providing broader access to athletic programs regardless of school attendance restrictions.

Title: Public Safety - Law Enforcement Agencies - Positive Community Feedback
Synopsis: Adding positive community feedback that was not solicited by the police officer who is the subject of the feedback to the list of records that are not considered personnel records; requiring the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop a process for citizens to submit positive community feedback; requiring each law enforcement agency to adopt the uniform citizen positive community feedback process; and requiring a law enforcement agency to maintain a certain record that is subject to public inspection.
bill_summary: The bill requires law enforcement agencies in Maryland to develop and adopt a uniform process for citizen feedback, specifically including positive community feedback. It also makes positive community feedback records, including unsolicited positive remarks, public records accessible under the Maryland Public Information Act.
responsible_party: Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission and law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Maryland residents and law enforcement officers
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a standardized process for collecting and publicly sharing positive community feedback about law enforcement officers, promoting transparency and positive community relations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Somerset County â€“ Fire, Rescue, and Emergency Medical Services
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Somerset County to enact local laws and adopt other measures to manage, direct, and regulate fire, rescue, and emergency medical services in the County; authorizing the County Commissioners to authorize or create an entity or a body to administer the County's affairs in the County relating to fire, rescue, and emergency medical services; and requiring the County Commissioners to establish an Emergency Services Advisory Council to make certain recommendations under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill grants Somerset County the authority to enact laws and measures to manage fire, rescue, and emergency medical services, including the creation of an entity or body to oversee these services and the establishment of an Emergency Services Advisory Council.
responsible_party: Somerset County Commissioners
stakeholders: Fire, rescue, and emergency medical services in Somerset County residents and agencies
innovative_summary: The bill introduces local governance structures for emergency services, including an advisory council, which is a standard approach to local emergency management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's impact on child poverty is indirect, mainly through improved emergency services efficiency and accessibility.

Title: Somerset County - Fire Companies - Appropriations
Synopsis: Requiring the County Commissioners of Somerset County to appropriate to certain organized volunteer fire companies in the county certain amounts for fiscal years 2025 through 2030; and requiring that the appropriations required for fiscal year 2030 remain in effect for subsequent fiscal years unless altered by a future enactment.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that Somerset County allocate and maintain specific annual funds for organized volunteer fire companies from FY 2025 through FY 2030, with the funds remaining in effect unless changed by future law.
responsible_party: Somerset County Government
stakeholders: Volunteer fire companies and residents of Somerset County
innovative_summary: The program formalizes consistent funding levels for volunteer fire companies over multiple years, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on fire company funding does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Somerset County â€“ Sale of Property â€“ Revells Neck Road
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Somerset County to sell the property at Map 32, Parcel 149 on Revells Neck Road under terms considered appropriate by the county commissioners.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Somerset County to sell certain surplus and specific properties, including a property on Revells Neck Road, through various methods such as sealed bids and negotiations, with some sales to government entities. It also sets procedures for bidding, advertising, and sale terms.
responsible_party: Somerset County Commissioners
stakeholders: Residents and government entities in Somerset County involved in property transactions
innovative_summary: The bill mainly updates procedures for county property sales and introduces flexibility in sale methods, with some provisions for specific property sales, but does not involve new technology or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily concerns property sale procedures.

Title: Agriculture - Invasive Plant Species - Regulation (Biodiversity and Agriculture Protection Act)
Synopsis: Altering the regulatory approach for controlling invasive plant species in the State, including repealing certain provisions of law relating to a two-tiered regulatory approach and requiring the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a list of prohibited invasive plants by regulation in a certain manner on or before October 1, 2024; establishing certain protocols for assessing certain nonnative plants and determining whether those plants are invasive or whether the plants may be placed on a certain watch list; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland's regulations on invasive plant species by establishing a new list of prohibited invasive plants, creating protocols for assessing nonnative plants, and setting requirements for reporting and managing invasive species, including signage and disposal.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture and Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Nurseries, plant dealers, landscapers, transportation agencies, environmental agencies, and the general public in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a systematic, science-based protocol for assessing and classifying invasive plants, integrating assessments, regulatory mechanisms, and public information systems, which demonstrates innovative approaches to invasive species management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly target child poverty; its focus is environmental regulation.

Title: Public Health - Opioid Restitution Advisory Council and Fund - Revisions
Synopsis: Requiring the Secretary of Health to present decisions for the allocations of money from the Opioid Restitution Fund to the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to post on the Department's website certain information regarding allocations of money from the Fund; and requiring the Department to report to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 1, 2024, on the best process for making the expenditures of all opioid settlement agreements accessible to the public.
bill_summary: The bill revises the operations of the Maryland Opioid Restitution Fund and its Advisory Council, clarifies decision-making and reporting processes for allocations, mandates posting of expenditure information online, and specifies funds usage for evidence-based and community recovery programs related to opioid use disorder.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals with substance use disorders, recovery organizations, and communities affected by opioid misuse
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency and accountability in opioid funding allocations, and introduces requirements for online posting and reporting, supporting data-driven and community-based approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill may indirectly impact child poverty through improved substance use disorder services and recovery support, but does not explicitly target child poverty.

Title: Principal Departments - Individuals With Limited English Proficiency - Access to Public Services
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before July 1, 2025, the principal departments of the Executive Branch to fully implement certain provisions of law requiring equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that Maryland state departments fully implement legal provisions to ensure equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency by July 1, 2025, including providing oral language services and translating vital documents.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Disabilities and other principal departments of the Executive Branch
stakeholders: Individuals with limited English proficiency in Maryland
innovative_summary: The program employs a comprehensive approach combining language services and translation of vital documents, with a clear phased implementation schedule across multiple agencies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Improving access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency can indirectly help reduce child poverty by improving access to essential services and resources.

Title: State Personnel - Maryland Department of Health - Pay Rates
Synopsis: Increasing the number of certain bargaining units for the purpose of specifying certain pay rates for certain employees of the Maryland Department of Health; and requiring that the pay rates of certain Department employees who are in certain bargaining units and who work at certain facilities be equal to certain pay rates of the employees who work at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital.
bill_summary: The bill increases pay rates for certain employees of the Maryland Department of Health, especially those working at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital and the Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents, aligning their pay to higher benchmarks and allowing pay adjustments based on specific criteria.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Employees of the Maryland Department of Health at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital and Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents
innovative_summary: This bill mostly updates pay structures based on existing benchmarks and classifications, with no new technologies or innovative approaches introduced.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly target child poverty but may improve wages for employees working with children and adolescents.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Coverage for the Treatment of Obesity - Required Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to study the impact of requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide comprehensive coverage for the treatment of obesity, including coverage for intensive behavioral therapy, bariatric surgery, and FDA-approved antiobesity medication; and requiring the Department to report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to study the impact of mandating comprehensive coverage for obesity treatment under Medicaid, including behavioral therapy, bariatric surgery, and FDA-approved antiobesity medications, and to report findings by the end of 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Medicaid recipients, individuals with obesity in Maryland, public health programs
innovative_summary: The bill employs a research and policy analysis approach to understanding the potential impact of expanded obesity treatment coverage, rather than implementing a new service or intervention.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential to reduce child poverty by improving health and reducing medical costs related to obesity, although the primary focus is on study and policy.

Title: Montgomery County â€“ Subdivision Plats â€“ Conditions PG/MC 111â€“24
Synopsis: Providing that the Montgomery County Planning Board may tentatively approve a subdivision plat subject to specified conditions; and providing for the approval and submission of a certain subdivision plat to the county land records.
bill_summary: This bill allows the Montgomery County Planning Board to tentatively approve subdivision plats with specific conditions before they are fully approved for recording, and it clarifies the process for final approval once conditions are met.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Planning Board
stakeholders: Developers and residents involved in subdivision development in Montgomery County
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a process for tentative approval of subdivision plats with conditions, streamlining the development approval process.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty but may indirectly facilitate housing development.

Title: Environment - Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reductions - Manufacturers
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "manufacturing" for purposes of certain greenhouse gas emissions reduction requirements to exclude the production of cement; altering the application of certain provisions of law regarding the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing sector to apply only to persons that engaged in manufacturing in 2023; requiring the Department of the Environment to make certain considerations and consult with certain stakeholders related to the regulation of the production of cement; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies Maryland's greenhouse gas emissions law by excluding cement production from the definition of manufacturing for emissions reduction purposes and sets specific considerations and stakeholder consultations related to cement regulation. It also limits the extent to which manufacturing emissions can be reduced below 2023 levels and enacts new rules and considerations for the regulation of cement production.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Manufacturers, particularly cement producers, and stakeholders involved in greenhouse gas regulation and reduction in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces specific considerations and stakeholder engagement for regulating emissions from cement manufacturing, including incentives and technological considerations, which reflects an evolving approach to sector-specific emissions regulation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but may indirectly affect the economy and employment in manufacturing sectors.

Title: Agriculture - Food Processing Residuals Utilization Permit - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing a food processing residuals utilization permit; prohibiting a person from utilizing food processing residuals in the State unless the person obtains a permit; requiring the Department of Agriculture to provide a certain notice and information to certain persons in a county where food processing residuals will be stored; establishing the Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund; authorizing a representative of the Department to enter and inspect any site where food processing residuals are utilized; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a permit system for the utilization of food processing residuals (food waste and related materials) in the State, sets regulations for permits, inspections, and storage, and creates a Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund to oversee programs including a certification program for commercial haulers.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture and Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Food processing residuals generators, agriculture operations, commercial haulers, local governments, and residents near land application sites
innovative_summary: The program introduces a specialized permit, inspection, and certification system for managing and land-aplying food processing residuals, and establishes a dedicated fund for oversight and costs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a limited potential for a direct impact on child poverty as it primarily focuses on environmental regulation and waste management.

Title: Environment - Delegated Authorities - Well and Septic Program Permits
Synopsis: Requiring a local health department or county government to which the Department of the Environment has delegated authority to administer a septic and well program to submit, by December 1, 2024, a schedule of review times for certain well and septic program permits for approval; and requiring a local health department or county government to submit well and septic program permit data to the Department for review beginning 3 months after the original schedule submission approved by the Department and every 3 months thereafter.
bill_summary: The bill requires local health departments and county governments with delegated authority to submit schedules and data related to well and septic system permits to the Maryland Department of the Environment, starting with submission of a review schedule by December 1, 2024, and ongoing periodic data submissions every three months.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Local health departments, county governments, residents with well and septic systems
innovative_summary: This program employs systematic data sharing and periodic reporting to improve oversight of well and septic system permits, utilizing existing government data infrastructure.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The programâ€™s impact on child poverty is likely minimal as it mainly focuses on permitting processes and oversight.

Title: Washington County Board of Education - Members - Residency Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring that a member of the Washington County Board of Education be a resident of Washington County for at least 6 months and the State for at least 12 months immediately preceding the date the member takes office; and requiring members of the county board to maintain a primary residence in Washington County during their term.
bill_summary: The bill requires members of the Washington County Board of Education to be residents of Washington County and the State for specified periods before taking office and to maintain primary residence in Washington County during their term. It also establishes a nominating commission for filling vacancies.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of Education and County Commissioners
stakeholders: Students, parents, and residents of Washington County
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a structured process for nominating and selecting school board members, including public hearings and a multi-member commission, emphasizing transparency and local community involvement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, mainly affecting governance and residency requirements.

Title: Consumer Protection - Consumer Council - Name Change
Synopsis: Changing the name of the Consumer Council in the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General to the Consumer Protection Commission.
bill_summary: The bill changes the name of the Consumer Council to the Consumer Protection Commission, modifies the composition and compensation of its members, and clarifies its advisory role in consumer protection programs.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General, Division of Consumer Protection
stakeholders: Consumers, consumer groups, business groups, public sector entities in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill mainly updates the organizational structure and rules for the consumer protection advisory body. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Maryland Department of Labor â€“ Unemployment Insurance â€“ Study on Actively Seeking Work Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Labor, on or before December 1, 2024, to conduct a study on the actively seeking work requirement of the unemployment insurance system in the State and other states to evaluate the effects of ghosting on actively seeking work requirements and report on the study to the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to study the effectiveness and verification processes of the 'actively seeking work' requirement for unemployment benefits, including factors like 'ghosting' by claimants and the capabilities of the current online system.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Unemployment benefit claimants and the Maryland workforce system
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on evaluating verification processes and the use of existing technology for unemployment insurance requirements, rather than introducing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it primarily involves a study of administrative processes.

Title: Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network to identify and analyze options for establishing and maintaining an open access science, technology, and innovation network or hub of citizen scientists and experts in science, technology, and industry for certain purposes; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a Workgroup to identify, analyze, and recommend how to create a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network through an open access, virtual platform for experts and citizens.
responsible_party: University of Maryland, Baltimore County
stakeholders: Scientists, technology experts, citizens, educational institutions, and industry in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill aims to create an open, virtual network for science and technology collaboration and exchange, leveraging modern digital methods to connect experts and promote innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential to impact child poverty indirectly by fostering innovation, education, and community engagement but does not target poverty directly.

Title: Office of the Attorney General - Investigative Authority - Health Care Fraud
Synopsis: Authorizing the Office of the Attorney General, a Deputy Attorney General, or an Assistant Attorney General to issue a subpoena to a person to produce certain materials, answer written interrogatories, and give certain testimony in furtherance of an ongoing health care fraud investigation under the Maryland False Health Claims Act or other civil authority; authorizing the Attorney General to report a failure to obey a certain subpoena to the circuit court with jurisdiction over the matter; etc.
bill_summary: This bill grants the Office of the Attorney General in Maryland investigative authority, including issuing subpoenas, to investigate health care fraud and related misconduct within state health programs. It establishes procedures for subpoena enforcement and outlines the agency's investigative powers.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General of Maryland
stakeholders: Healthcare providers, Medicaid recipients, and vulnerable populations affected by health care fraud
innovative_summary: The bill enhances government investigative tools by explicitly authorizing subpoena powers and enforcement procedures for health care fraud investigations, using existing legal frameworks with specific enhancements for health-related investigations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has the potential to reduce child poverty indirectly by ensuring integrity and accountability in health care programs that serve vulnerable populations, including children.

Title: Montgomery County - Clerk of the Circuit Court - Plat Recordation PG/MC 110-24
Synopsis: Authorizing a plat in Montgomery County to be drawn, recorded, and maintained in electronic form in a manner approved by the State Archivist.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Montgomery County to record and maintain subdivision plats in electronic form approved by the State Archivist, updating record-keeping procedures.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Clerk of the Circuit Court and State Archivist
stakeholders: Property owners, land surveyors, and government agencies in Montgomery County
innovative_summary: The bill introduces electronic plat recordation approved by the State Archivist, modernizing record-keeping practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Average Final Compensation - Compensation Adjustments
Synopsis: Establishing that certain adjustments to compensation may not be considered an extraordinary salary increase when determining the average final compensation of a member in the State Retirement and Pension System; and requiring a member to submit certain information to the State Retirement Agency in a certain manner at the time of retirement.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies that certain compensation adjustments cannot be considered extraordinary salary increases when calculating the average final compensation for retirement benefits under the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System. It also requires members to submit specific documentation at retirement if they received certain adjustment related salary increases.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, particularly those with salary adjustments near retirement
innovative_summary: The bill employs a procedural change requiring members to submit documentation at retirement to accurately account for salary adjustments, standardizing how compensation increases are considered in retirement calculations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's impact on child poverty is minimal as it primarily changes rules related to retirement calculations for public employees.

Title: Correctional Officers' Retirement System - Membership
Synopsis: Altering membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System to include certain employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Department of Health; requiring the State Retirement and Pension System to transfer the creditable service of employees transferred into the Correctional Officers' Retirement System under the Act unless the employee elects not to transfer service on or before June 1, 2025; authorizing certain employees to elect not to transfer service; etc.
bill_summary: The bill expands membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System to include certain employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Health, allows transfer of unused sick leave credits, adjusts benefit calculations for some retirees, and sets provisions for transfer of service credits and disability benefits, with some provisions expiring after one year.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Department of Health, and correctional officers
innovative_summary: The bill employs a combination of membership expansion, service credit transfer, and benefit adjustment provisions, some of which involve novel approaches to crediting unused sick leave and service; however, it primarily updates existing pension rules.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it primarily focuses on correctional employee retirement benefits.

Title: Public Health â€“ Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program â€“ Recovery of Funding
Synopsis: Altering the number of years after completion of a project funded in part by a grant of the Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program after which the State may recover funding under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill amends rules regarding the recovery of funding from federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) in Maryland, specifically extending the time frame for the state to recover funds if property ceases to be an FQHC or is transferred, from 15 to 30 years depending on the circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health or Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Federally qualified health centers, property owners, local communities served by FQHCs
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a longer recovery timeline for the state to reclaim funds, aligning recovery periods with the long-term assets of health centers, but does not employ new technologies or radically new approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill potentially supports the stability and continuity of federally qualified health centers, which can improve health outcomes and reduce child poverty indirectly.

Title: State Officers and Employees â€“ Required Surety Bonds â€“ Insurance Policies Authorized
Synopsis: Altering the requirements that certain officers and employees of the State be covered by certain surety bonds to allow the officers and employees to be covered by certain insurance policies; transferring certain duties and responsibilities of the Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee to the State Treasurer; and repealing certain provisions of law related to the approval, form, and record of certain surety bonds required for certain officers and employees of the State.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the use of insurance policies in lieu of surety bonds for certain Maryland state officers and employees, modifies the procedures for bond approval and record-keeping, and transfers some duties from the Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee to the State Treasurer. It updates laws across multiple articles relating to bond and insurance requirements for various state officials and staff.
responsible_party: Maryland State Treasurer's Office and relevant state agencies
stakeholders: Maryland state officers, employees, and officials who require bonds or insurance coverage
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a flexible approach by allowing insurance policies as an alternative to traditional surety bonds, integrating modern financial instruments into government oversight and reducing reliance on surety bonds.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it mainly updates administrative and legal requirements for bonds and insurance for state officials.

Title: State Employees - Paid Sick Leave - Certificate of Illness or Disability Signed by a Licensed Clinical Professional Counselor
Synopsis: Authorizing a licensed clinical professional counselor to sign a certificate of illness or disability when a State employee uses sick leave for 5 or more consecutive workdays.
bill_summary: The bill allows licensed clinical professional counselors to sign certificates of illness or disability for Maryland state employees when they take sick leave beyond 5 days, enabling employees to provide valid medical certification from this new group of healthcare providers.
responsible_party: Maryland State Government, Department of Personnel and Pensions
stakeholders: Maryland state employees who take sick leave beyond 5 days, licensed clinical professional counselors
innovative_summary: This bill expands the authority of health care providers authorized to verify employee sick leave, including licensed clinical counselors, which introduces a broader scope of healthcare professionals in the certification process.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill may indirectly benefit child poverty by ensuring better access to sick leave certification, supporting workers' health and stability.

Title: Frederick County - School Construction Master Plan Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup; and requiring the Workgroup to comprehensively evaluate all school facility needs in Frederick County and report its findings and recommendations to certain Frederick County officials, the Interagency Commission on School Construction and the Frederick County House and Senate Delegations by December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup, which will evaluate school facility needs and explore funding solutions for school construction, maintenance, and renovations. The Workgroup will report its findings by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Frederick County Board of Education
stakeholders: Students, families, and staff in Frederick County Public Schools
innovative_summary: The program employs a collaborative workgroup to evaluate school infrastructure needs and explore cost-saving and funding strategies, which is a systematic and inclusive approach but uses existing structures.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could have a direct impact on child poverty by improving school facilities, which can enhance educational environments and opportunities.

Title: Boundary of the Frederick County Soil Conservation District - Alteration
